abstract.t: This document proposes updates to the ECMAScript media types, superseding the existing registrations for “application/javascript” and “text/javascript” by adding an additional extension and removing usage warnings. This document updates RFC4329, “Scripting Media Types”.

note.title: Note to Readers
note.t: The issues list for this draft can be found at https://github.com/bmeck/I-D/labels/javascript-mjs.
The most recent (often, unpublished) draft is at https://github.com/bmeck/I-D/tree/master/javascript-mjs.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document updates the existing media types for the ECMAScript programming language. It supersedes the media types registrations in for “application/javascript” and “text/javascript”.

section.title: Background
section.t: In order to formalize support for modular programs now defines two top-level goal symbols for the ECMAScript grammar. This means that (in the absence of additional information) there are two possible interpretations for any given ECMAScript Source Text. The TC39 standards body for ECMAScript has determined that media types are outside of their scope of work .

It is not possible to fully determine if a Source Text of ECMAScript is meant to be parsed in the Module or Script grammar goals based upon content alone. Therefore, scripting environments must use out of band information in order to determine what goal a Source Text should be treated as. To this end some scripting environments have chosen to adopt a new file extension of .mjs for determining the goal of a given Source Text.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: The media type registrations herein are divided into two major categories: the sole media type “text/javascript” which is now in common usage, and all of the media types that are obsolete.

For both categories, The ECMAScript media types are to be updated to point to a non-vendor specific standard undated specification of ECMAScript. In addition, a new file extension of .mjs is to be added to the list of file extensions with the restriction that it must correspond to the Module grammar of . Finally, the specification is using “text/javascript” as the default media type of ECMAScript when preparing script tags; therefore, “text/javascript” has been moved intended usage from OBSOLETE to COMMON.

list.t: goal, declares the goal symbol in the Syntactic Grammars of to be used while parsing. This parameter is case insensitive.
Encoding is host dependent with differences in byte order marks, the charset parameter, and text preprocessing.
See notes in various sections of . This media type does not specify the grammar of used when missing the goal parameter.

t.hangText: Applications which use this media type:
Person & email address to contact for further information:

list.t: The file extension .mjs must be parsed using the Module grammar of

section.title: Historic Javascript Media Types
section.t: The following media types are added or updated for historical purposes. All herein have an intended usage of OBSOLETE, and are not expected to be in use with modern implementations.

list.t: goal, declares the goal symbol in the Syntactic Grammars of to be used while parsing. This parameter is case insensitive.
Encoding is host dependent with differences in byte order marks, the charset parameter, and text preprocessing.
See notes in various sections of . This media type does not specify the grammar of used when missing the goal parameter.

t.hangText: Applications which use this media type:
Person & email address to contact for further information:

list.t: This media type is obsolete; current implementations should use text/javascript as the only javascript/ECMAscript media type. The file extension .mjs must be parsed using the Module grammar of
